conclusion: Stirling cycle on a P-V diagram with states A, B, C, D; processes A→B and C→D are isothermal.
P-V diagram is a graph of pressure vs. volume; area under curve represents work done.
Stirling cycle involves two isothermal and two constant volume processes.
Diagram shows points A, B, C, D with arrows indicating path: A to B, B to C, C to D, D to A.
A→B is isothermal, PV = constant, likely a hyperbola.
A is at high pressure and low volume, B is at lower pressure and higher volume.
A→B is isothermal expansion; pressure decreases, volume increases.
In isothermal expansion, work done by gas is positive.
Since ΔU = 0 in isothermal process, Q = W; heat absorbed equals work done.
Work is done by the gas, so Q is positive; heat is absorbed.
In isothermal expansion, gas absorbs heat from surroundings.
B→C: Pressure decreases slightly, volume constant; C→D: Isothermal compression; D→A: Constant volume heating.
Cycle: A→B (isothermal expansion), B→C (constant volume cooling), C→D (isothermal compression), D→A (constant volume heating).
A→B is isothermal expansion, involves heat absorption.
In isothermal process, ΔU = 0, work done by gas equals heat absorbed.
A→B is expansion, work done by gas, heat absorbed to compensate.
Final conclusion: The gas absorbs heat when moving from state A to state B.
